title: Iraq protest deaths soar past 200, curfew returns
text:
Iraq's military has reinstated a nightly curfew in that country until further notice, in an effort stave off anti-government protests that returned over the weekend with renewed ferocity.

This was Baghdad on Monday (October 28).

The death toll for the month of October stands at about 230 or more.

One man said this isn't protest, it's "a revolution."

"We're taking to the streets in a peaceful demonstration" said another protester on Monday. He wants the constitution and election laws changed.

The protests had calmed for about two weeks. It began as cries against high unemployment and lack of progress in the country, but as anger grew so did its focus.

Particular anger is given to politicians seen as pawns in the power-play between the United States and Iran.

There's also outrage over the role of militia groups in the security services, including those backed by Iran.

Militia members have turned their guns on protesters, killing scores.

Protesters have torched offices of all the major political parties, as well as buildings owned by militias and government.
description:
Iraq's military has reinstated a nightly curfew in that country until further notice, in an effort stave off anti-government protests that returned over the weekend with renewed ferocity. 
              This was Baghdad on Monday (October 28). 
              The death toll for the month of October stands at about 230 or more. 
              One man said this isn't protest, it's "a revolution." 
              "We're taking to the streets in a peaceful demonstration" said another protester on Monday. He wants the constitution and election laws changed. 
              The protests had calmed for about two weeks. It began as cries against high unemployment and lack of progress in the country, but as anger grew so did its focus. 
              Particular anger is given to politicians seen as pawns in the power-play between the United States and Iran. 
              There's also outrage over the role of militia groups in the security services, including those backed by Iran. 
              Militia members have turned their guns on protesters, killing scores. 
              Protesters have torched offices of all the major political parties, as well as buildings owned by militias and government.
